Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Carbon-Carbon Single Bond Activation - Mechanistic Comparisons and Reaction Development
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this CAREER award funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Jeffrey B. Johnson of the Department of Chemistry at Hope College will pursue a mechanistic understanding of the process of carbon-carbon single bond activation by transition metal catalysts. The proposed research will begin with the detailed mechanistic analysis of three known transition metal-catalyzed C-C bond activation reactions. Data compiled from these studies will provide insight into factors that influence the activation of C-C single bonds, reveal mechanistic pathways and catalytic intermediates, and subsequently guide the development of more general and powerful reaction methodologies.

Although C-C single bonds are ubiquitous within organic chemistry, this chemical moiety is generally considered inert - few reactions selectively cleave and functionalize C-C bonds. New methods hold the promise of a new paradigm that may have profound implication for the construction of biologically active molecules, natural products and pharmaceutical compounds. Carrying out the proposed research at an undergraduate institution will involve undergraduate students as the sole researchers on all facets of the work. These students will have the opportunity to extend their classroom experiences and explore new subjects such as organometallic chemistry, catalysis, and kinetic and mechanistic studies, while also developing skills required for success in any field. This project also supports a collaboration with the Hope College Upward Bound Program, a program that assists at-risk high school students prepare for college and thus promotes the improvement of diversity within STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carbon-carbon single bonds make up the structural backbone of organic molecules--compounds as varied as plastics, plant matter or pharmaceuticals--and are unreactive in the vast majority of reaction conditions. But in this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Jeffrey B. Johnson of the Department of Chemistry at Hope College and his group of undergraduate researchers have pursued a mechanistic investigation into some of the few processes that proceed through the cleavage of carbon-carbon single bonds. This greater understanding of the phenomenon has led to the development of new and more general methods to activate these bonds and subsequently transform readily available starting materials into significantly more complex and valuable products. Work in this grant period has led to a total of 7 papers, training of 42 students in various aspects of the research process, and led to a series of new research avenues that will be pursued for years to come.

The primary impact of carrying out the proposed research at an undergraduate institution has been the involvement of undergraduate students as the sole researchers on all facets of the work. Over 40 students contributed to projects supported by this grant, exploring new subjects such as organometallic chemistry, catalysis, and kinetic and mechanistic studies, while also developing skills required for success in any field, including the ability to think critically, to organize and analyze complex data, and to communicate their findings. The combined effort of these students led to 2 papers describing mechanistic investigations and an additional 5 that describe new methods utilizing carbon-carbon activation. In addition, students have presented 62 presentations at regional and national meetings. Of the 42 students to have worked on aspects of this research, 34 have graduated from college (8 will graduate over the next 2 years.) Of the graduates, 17 students proceeded on to graduate school in chemistry or related fields, 9 students continued on to medical and dental schools, 5 are currently working within the chemical industry, and 3 are teaching high school chemistry. Even if the technical skills are not directly applicable, the skillset these students have acquired in the research process will be of significant benefit in their future career paths.

Beyond the fundamental laboratory research, aspects of this project reached the general education curriculum at Hope College. A series of classes taught to non-science majors included aspects of green chemistry, biotechnology and neuroscience, while generally promoting the importance of basic scientific literacy among the general public. The project also supported a collaboration with the Hope College Upward Bound Program, a program that assists at-risk high school students prepare for college. Undergraduate student researchers worked with these students on a routine basis, preparing hands-on experiential activities to promote engagement with and enthusiasm for science. Over 80% of these students have continued on to post-secondary education, many in science-related areas of study, ultimately improving the diversity with STEM fields.
